https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/operational-pilot/trustmark-definitions/ficam-loa-2-registration-and-issuance-requirements/1.0/ https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/operational-pilot/trustmark-definitions/ficam-loa-2-registration-and-issuance-requirements/1.0/trustmark-reference/ FICAM LOA 2 Registration and Issuance Requirements 1.0 This Trustmark Definition adopts the LOA 2 Registration and Issuance trust criteria of the FICAM Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process. 2014-10-07T09:57:01 https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/ Georgia Tech Research Institute PRIMARY TrustmarkFeedback@gtri.gatech.edu 404-407-8956 75 5th Street NW, Suite 900, Atlanta, GA 30308 Stakeholders of the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance as defined by the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the FICAM TFS. Credential Service Providers that wish to assert identities to either federal relying parties or relying parties that utilize the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance. U.S. federal relying parties and other relying parties that utilize the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance. Current or prospective FICAM-approved trust framework providers (TFPs), or Trustmark Providers that specialize in assessments concerning the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance.

Any organization or business entity may act as a Trustmark Provider for trustmarks under this Trustmark Definition.

]]>

Any individual employed or contracted by the Trustmark Provider may act as the assessor for trustmarks under this Trustmark Definition.

]]>

For any trustmark issued under this Trustmark Definition, the Trustmark Provider must revoke the trustmark upon any condition whereby one or more Conformance Criteria cease to be satisfied.

]]>

This Trustmark Definition requires no extension data.

]]> This document and the information contained herein is provided on an "AS IS" basis, and the Georgia Tech Research Institute disclaims all warranties, express or implied, including but not limited to any warranty that the use of the information herein will not infringe any rights or any implied warranties or merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose. In addition, the Georgia Tech Research Institute disclaims legal liability for any loss incurred as a result of the use or reliance on the document or the information contained herein. The Georgia Tech Research Institute (GTRI) has published this document with the support of the National Strategy for Trusted Identities in Cyberspace (NSTIC) via the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). The views expressed herein do not necessarily reflect the official policies of GTRI, NIST or NSTIC; nor does mention of trade names, commercial practices, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. adopted authentication scheme / adopted scheme An open identity management standard that the ICAM assesses, approves, and scopes for use across the federal government. An adopted scheme meets all applicable ICAM requirements, as well as other federal statutes, regulations, and policies. In addition, the structured adoption process provides assurance to all ICAM participants that underlying identity assurance technologies are appropriate, robust, reliable, and secure.

]]> applicant A party undergoing the processes of registration and identity proofing.

]]> approved cryptographic method FIPS approved or NIST recommend. An algorithm or technique that is either (1) specified in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation, or (2) adopted in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation.

]]> authentication assertion A statement from a verifier to an RP that may contain identity and attribute information about a subscriber, as well as information about an authentication event that has been completed with the subscriber.

]]> authentication factor A category of tokens that is either "something you know" (e.g., a password), "something you have" (e.g., a cryptographic key), or "something you are" (e.g., a fingerprint).

]]> authentication protocol / authentication scheme A defined sequence of messages between a claimant and a verifier that demonstrates that the claimant has possession and control of a valid token to establish his/her identity, and optionally, demonstrates to the claimant that he or she is communicating with the intended verifier. An authentication protocol may also define the generation of an authentication assertion to be provided to an RP.

]]> authentication protocol run An exchange of messages between a claimant and a verifier that executes an authentication protocol and results in authentication, or authentication failure, between the two parties.

]]> claimant A party whose identity is to be verified using an authentication protocol.

]]> credential An object or data structure that authoritatively binds an identity (and optionally, additional attributes) to a token possessed and controlled by a subscriber. A credential may be maintained by the subscriber to which the credential was issued or by the CSP that issued the credential.

]]> credential service provider CSP An entity that issues or registers subscriber tokens and issues credentials to subscribers (i.e, a CSP conducts the issuance process). A CSP may encompass RAs and verifiers that it operates. A CSP may be an independent third party, or may issue credentials for its own use.

]]> established policy, procedure, or practice statement A policy, procedure, or practice statement that has been formally adopted and put into use by an entity.

]]> established technical capability The ability to accurately implement and maintain, as part of normal business operations, a technical mechanism for achieving some goal.

]]> external RA designee An RA designee that is governed by an entity other than the CSP that it serves.

]]> external verifier designee A verifier designee that is governed by an entity other the CSP that it serves.

]]> Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management FICAM An initiative for implementing ICAM principles within the U.S. Federal Government.

]]> Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management Trust Framework Solutions FICAM TFS The federated identity framework for the U.S. Federal Government.

]]> Identity, Credential, and Access Management ICAM A federal program that focuses on addressing challenges, pressing issues, and design requirements for digital identity, credential, and access management and defining and promoting consistency across approaches for implementing ICAM programs as reflected in the FICAM Roadmap & Implementation Guidance

]]> Identity, Credential, and Access Management Sub-Committee ICAMSC A committee established in 2008 under the Federal CIO Council's Information Security and Identity Management Committee (ISIMC) and tasked with aligning the identity management activities of the Federal Government..

]]> identity proofing The process by which a CSP and an RA collect and verify information about a person for the purpose of issuing credentials to that person.

]]> identity provider IDP A system used to perform the token / credential validation functions of a CSP and the authentication and assertion issuance functions of a verifier.

]]> issuance The process of issuing tokens or credentials to a subscriber of a CSP.

]]> level of assurance LOA The degree of confidence in the vetting process used to establish the identity of an individual to whom the credential was issued and the degree of confidence that the individual who uses the credential is the individual to whom the credential was issued. Also, see the use of assurance in [OMB M-04-04].

]]> LOA 2 level of assurance 2. As defined in [OMB M-04-04], LOA 2 means "Some confidence in an asserted identity's validity". This is in contrast to levels 1, 3, and 4, which mean "little or no", "high", and "very high", respectively, in regards to assurance in an asserted identity's validity.

]]> LOA 2 adopted authentication scheme An adopted authentication scheme approved for use at LOA 2.

]]> LOA 2 applicant An applicant that has applied to go through an LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 2 authentication assertion An authentication assertion that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 authentication protocol An authentication protocol that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 credential A credential that that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 identity proofing An identity proofing process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 issuance An issuance process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 registration A registration process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 registration and issuance A sequence of registration and issuance processes that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 shared secret file A shared secret file that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 subscriber A subscriber that has gone through a LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 2 token A token that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 token authenticator A token authenticator generated by an LOA 2 token.

]]> LOA 3 level of assurance 3. As defined in [OMB M-04-04], LOA 3 means "high confidence in an asserted identity's validity". This is in contrast to levels 1, 2, and 4, which mean "little or no", "some", and "very high", respectively, in regards to assurance in an asserted identity's validity.

]]> LOA 3 adopted authentication scheme An adopted authentication scheme approved for use at LOA 3.

]]> LOA 3 applicant An applicant that has applied to go through an LOA 3 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 3 authentication assertion An authentication assertion that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 authentication protocol An authentication protocol that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 credential A credential that that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 identity proofing An identity proofing process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 issuance An issuance process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 registration A registration process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 registration and issuance A sequence of registration and issuance processes that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 shared secret file A shared secret file that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 subscriber A subscriber that has gone through a LOA 3 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 3 token A token that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 token authenticator A token authenticator generated by an LOA 3 token.

]]> multi-factor token A token that uses two or more factors to achieve authentication.

]]> multi-stage authentication An authentication scheme, or series of authentication schemes used together, in which one token is used to obtain a second token.

]]> multi-token authentication An authentication scheme in which the claimant presents token authenticators generated by two or more tokens (not using a multi-stage process) to prove his or her identity to the verifier. The combination of tokens is characterized by the combination of factors used by the tokens (both inherent in the manifestation of the tokens, and those used to activate the tokens).

]]> NIST National Institute of Standards and Technology.

]]> OMB United States Office of Management and Budget.

]]> personally identifiable information PII Information which can be used to distinguish or trace an individual's identity, such as their name, social security number, biometric records, etc. alone, or when combined with other personal or identifying information which is linked or linkable to a specific individual, such as date and place of birth, mother's maiden name, etc.

]]> policy A statement of criteria to which an entity is expected to conform.

]]> practice statement A formal statement of the practices followed by a party. A practice statement usually describes the policies and practices of the party and can become legally binding.

]]> procedure A sequence of steps that achieves some stated goal.

]]> process See "procedure"

]]> RA designee An RA designated by a particular CSP to conduct LOA 2 registration or LOA 2 identity proofing processes on behalf of that CSP. An RA designee may be governed directly by the relying CSP (e.g., a department or business unit of the CSP), or by an entity external to the relying CSP.

]]> registration authority RA An entity that establishes and vouches for the identity or attributes of a subscriber to a CSP. The RA may be an integral part of a CSP, or it may be independent of a CSP, but it has a relationship to the CSP(s). It is important for an RA to be trusted by the CSPs and applicants that it serves and RPs that rely on the identity proofing that it does.

]]> registration and issuance The sequence of the registration and issuance processes.

]]> registration The process through which an applicant applies to become a subscriber of a CSP and an RA validates the identity of the applicant on behalf of the CSP. In other words, registration includes identity proofing and refers to the registration by an RA of the results of performing identity proofing on an applicant.

]]> relying party RP An entity that relies upon a subscriber's credentials or verifier's assertion of an identity, typically to process a transaction or grant access to an information system.

]]> shared secret A secret used in authentication that is known to the claimant and the verifier.

]]> shared secret file A file held by a CSP or verifier that contains secrets held between the CSP or verifier and its subscribers or claimants.

]]> single-factor token A token that uses one of the three factors to achieve authentication.

]]> single-token authentication An authentication scheme in which the claimant presents a single token authenticator to prove his or her identity to the verifier.

]]> subscriber A party who has received a credential or token from a CSP.

]]> TFPAP Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process, v2.0.2. See [TFPAP].

]]> token Something that a claimant possess and controls (typically a cryptographic module or password) that is used to authenticate the claimant's identity.

]]> token authenticator The output value generated by a token. This value is one that is provided to a protocol stack to prove that a claimant possess and controls a token. Protocol messages sent to a verifier are dependent upon the token authenticator, but may or may not explicitly contain it.

]]> verifier An entity that verifies a claimant's identity by verifying the claimant's possession and control of a token using an authentication protocol. To do this, the verifier may also need to validate credentials that link the token and identity and check their status.

]]> verifier designee A verifier designated by a particular CSP to conduct LOA 2 authentication protocol run processes on behalf of that CSP. A verifier designee may be governed by the CSP (e.g., a department or business unit of the CSP), or by an entity external to the CSP.

]]> SP 800-63-2 NIST SP 800-63-2: Electronic Authentication Guideline, August, 2013 OMB M-04-04 Office of Management and Budget Memorandum M-04-04, December 16, 2003 TFPAP LOA 2 FICAM TFS Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process for All Levels of Assurance, v2.0.2, March, 14, 2014, Appendix A-2: Assurance Level 2 1 Trusted relationship between the CSP and its RA designees The CSP MUST ensure that a trusted relationship always exists between itself and each of its LOA 2 RA designees. Also, the CSP MUST ensure that mechanisms or policies are in place to ensure that it knows the obligations of each LOA 2 RA designee and each LOA 2 RA designee knows the obligations of the CSP.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 1]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 2 Trusted RAs perform identity proofing The CSP MUST ensure that every LOA 2 applicant goes through an LOA 2 identity proofing process by a trusted RA designee before becoming an LOA 2 subscriber of the CSP.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 2]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 3 Resist the threat of token issuance disclosure The CSP MUST ensure that LOA 2 tokens are issued only in a manner that protects the confidentiality of information related to the token, and thereby resist the threat of token issuance disclosure.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 3]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 4 Resist the threat of token issuance tampering The CSP MUST establish a procedure that allows its LOA 2 subscribers to authenticate the CSP as the source of any LOA 2 token or LOA 2 credential data that he or she may receive, and thereby resist the threat of token issuance tampering.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 4]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 5 Resist the threat of unauthorized token issuance The CSP MUST establish a procedure to ensure that the individual who receives an LOA 2 token is the same individual who participated in the registration procedure, and thereby resist the threat of unauthorized token issuance.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 5]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 6 Resist the threat of registration repudiation The CSP MUST resist the threat of registration repudiation and protect against an LOA 2 subscriber denying registration and claiming that they did not register a particular LOA 2 token.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 6]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 7 Protect sensitive data The CSP MUST ensure the security and confidentiality at all times (e.g., during transmission and storage) of sensitive data, including PII.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 7]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 8 Protect the results of identity proofing The CSP MUST ensure that the results of its LOA 2 identity proofing processes (which may include background investigations of applicants) are protected to ensure source authentication, confidentiality, and integrity.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 8]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 9 Maintain records of applicants The CSP MUST ensure that it and its LOA 2 RA designees collectively maintain a record of each LOA 2 applicant whose identity has been verified, the steps taken to verify his or her identity, a record of the facts of registration and identity proofing, and any information collected from him or her.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 9]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 10 Having the capability to provide identity proofing records The CSP MUST have the capability to provide records of LOA 2 identity proofing to RPs if required.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 10]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 11 Having written policies that govern the registration processes The CSP MUST ensure that all its RA designees have written established policies or established practice statements that govern their LOA 2 registration processes and specifies the particular steps taken to verify identities. Written established practice statements should address the primary objectives of registration and identity proofing.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 11]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 12 Securing remote communications between the CSP and RAs The CSP MUST ensure that every LOA 2 registration transaction, that includes its RA designees or itself communicating remotely over a network, uses approved cryptography and meets one of the following requirements.

  1. The transaction MUST occur over a mutually-authenticated protected session.

  2. The transaction MUST consist of time-stamped or sequenced messages signed by the source and encrypted for the recipient.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 12]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 13 Unique identification of each subscriber The CSP MUST be able to uniquely identify each LOA 2 subscriber and the associated tokens and credentials issued to that subscriber under an LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence. The CSP MUST be capable of conveying this information to verifiers.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 13]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 14 Maintain the actual identity of each subscriber The CSP MUST ensure that, among itself and all its RA designees, the actual identity of each LOA 2 subscriber is known, even for subscribers who are issued pseudonymous identities.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 14]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 15 Distinguish between pseudonymous credentials and verified credentials The CSP MUST ensure that all pseudonymous LOA 2 credentials are distinguishable from LOA 2 credentials that contain verified names.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 14]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 16 Protect PII The CSP MUST ensure that PII collected as part of the registration process is protected.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 15]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 17 Registering identity proofing information The CSP MUST ensure that, during every LOA 2 identity proofing process, each LOA 2 applicant supplies his or her full legal name, an address of record, date of birth, and other PII required by the CSP or the registering RA designee.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 16]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 18 Registration requirements for in-person identity proofing The CSP MUST ensure that, during in-person LOA 2 identity proofing processes, each applicant presents a valid current primary government picture ID that contains the applicant's picture, and either address of record or nationality (e.g. driver's license or passport).

In addition, the CSP MUST ensure that, during in-person LOA 2 identity proofing processes, its RA designees inspect the applicant-supplied picture ID, confirm that the picture matches the applicant, and record the ID number, and if applicable, the address and date of birth.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 17]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 19 Issuance requirements for in-person identity proofing The CSP MUST ensure that, after the execution of an in-person LOA 2 identity proofing process, one of the following methods of credential issuance is followed.

  1. The CSP issues credentials in a manner that confirms the ability of the applicant to receive telephone communications or text message at a phone number or email address associated with the applicant in records. Any secret sent over an unprotected session is reset upon first use.

  2. If the picture ID confirms the applicant's address of record, then the RA designee sends notice of credential issuance authorization to the applicant's address of record, or the CSP sends notice of credential issuance to the applicant's address of record.

  3. If the picture ID does not confirm the applicant's address of record, then the CSP issues credentials in a manner that confirms address of record.

  4. If the CSP is an employer or educational institution, then the CSP issues credentials to employees or students in-person by inspection of a corporate or school issued picture ID.

  5. If the CSP is an employer or educational institution, then the CSP designee issues credentials to employees or students through online processes, where notification is sent via the distribution channels normally used for sensitive, personal communications.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 17]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 20 Registration requirements for remote identity proofing The CSP MUST conform to each of the following.

  1. The CSP MUST ensure that, during remote LOA 2 identity proofing processes, each applicant presents a valid government ID (e.g. a driver's license or passport) number, and a financial or utility account number (e.g., checking account, savings account, utility account, loan or credit card, or tax ID) confirmed via records of either the government ID or account number.

  2. The CSP MUST ensure that an RA designee inspects both the ID number and the account number (e.g., for the correct number of digits).

  3. The CSP MUST ensure that an RA designee verifies the information provided by the applicant, including ID number or account number, through record checks either with the applicable agency or institution, or through credit bureaus or similar databases, and confirms that the name, date of birth, address, and other personal information in records are on balance consistent with the application and sufficient to identify a unique individual.

  4. If the CSP allows the use of utility account numbers in its identity proofing processes, then it MUST ensure that an RA designee verifies the utility account number by verifying the applicant's knowledge of recent account activity.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 18]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 21 Issuance requirements for remote identity proofing The CSP MUST ensure that, after the successful execution of a remote LOA 2 identity proofing process, one of the following methods of credential issuance is followed.

  1. The CSP issues credentials in a manner that confirms the ability of the applicant to receive mail at a physical address associated with the applicant in records.

  2. The CSP issues credentials in a manner that confirms the ability of the applicant to receive telephone communications or text messages at the phone number or email address associated with the applicant in records. Any secret sent over an unprotected channel MUST be reset upon first use and MUST be valid for a maximum lifetime of seven days.

  3. The CSP issues credentials and either the CSP or an RA designee sends notice of credential issuance to an address of record confirmed during identity proofing.

  4. If the CSP is an employer or educational institution, then the CSP issues credentials to employees or students in-person by inspection of a corporate or school issued picture ID.

  5. If the CSP is an employer or educational institution, then the CSP issues credentials to employees or students through online processes, where notification is via the distribution channels normally used for sensitive, personal communications.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 18]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 22 Ensure the same party acts as applicant in-person The CSP MUST ensure that the same party always acts as the applicant during the execution of an LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence that are facilitated by in-person encounters with the applicant, by requiring the applicant to identify himself/herself by one of the following methods:

  1. Presenting a temporary secret which was established during a prior transaction or encounter, or sent to the applicant's phone number, email address, or physical address of record.

  2. Using a biometric that was recorded during a prior encounter.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 19]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 23 Ensure the same party acts as applicant remotely The CSP MUST ensure that the same party always acts as the applicant during the execution of an LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence that is facilitated by electronic transactions with the applicant, by requiring the applicant to identify himself/herself in any new transaction (beyond the first transaction or encounter) by presenting a temporary secret which was established during a prior transaction or encounter, or sent to the applicant's phone number, email address, or physical address of record.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 19]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 24 Identity proofing licensed professionals If an RA designee of the CSP rigorously confirms the identity, education, and licensing credentials of a licensed professional in accordance with federal or state law or regulations, and through an in-person appearance prior to employment or affiliation, then the CSP MAY issue LOA 2 credentials to such licensed professionals without repeating the identity proofing process, if the following requirements are met.

  1. The initial process for confirming the identity, education, and licensing credentials of the licensed professional includes the following steps.

    1. The RA designee verifies that the applicant has a current primary government picture ID that contains the applicant's picture, and either address or nationality of record (e.g., a driver's license or passport).

    2. The RA designee verifies two or more years of post-secondary education or training appropriate for the applicant's position (e.g., an appropriate medical degree).

    3. The RA designee verifies that the state or federal licensure of the applicant (e.g., as a physician) is current, is based on an examination process, and includes requirements for continuing education or active professional participation as a condition of valid licensing.

  2. The CSP MUST issue tokens and credentials to the licensed professional either in-person, or via a remote issuance process that incorporates the address and phone number confirmation as appropriate for LOA 2.

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 20]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> 25 Issuing derived credentials The CSP MAY issue derived LOA 2 credentials to a claimant if the following requirements are met.

  1. The CSP MUST ensure that, before issuing any derived credential to a claimant, it verifies the original credential status and verifies that the corresponding token is possessed and controlled by the claimant.

  2. The CSP SHOULD re-check the status of the original credential at a later date (e.g. after a week) to confirm that the credential was not compromised at the time of issuance of the derived credential. (This guards against the case where an Attacker requests the desired credential before revocation information can be updated.)

]]> Registration and Issuance Table, Item 21]]> Section 5: Registration and Issuance Processes]]> For assessment steps that require the verification that there are established policies or procedures that demonstrate conformance to a particular conformance criterion, there is an implied requirement to verify that there are no established policies or procedures that demonstrate non-conformance to that criterion. This can be facilitated by documenting references to sections of established policies and procedures that explicitly enumerate the entirety of the relevant items that need to be verified for conformance.

To answer an assessment step as not applicable, the assessor must document references to, and explanatory annotations of, sections of established policies or procedures of the Trustmark Applicant, its RA designees, or its CSP designees, that provide supporting evidence of why the assessment step should be answered as not applicable.

Assessors should use [SP 800-63-2 Reg and Iss] as a guide for determining acceptable threat mitigation mechanisms.

]]> 1 Policy for ensuring a trusted relationship between the CSP and its RA designees Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that it maintains a trusted relationship with each of its RA designees, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 2 Policy for ensuring trusted RA designees conduct identity proofing Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that it ensures that only trusted RA designees conduct LOA 2 identity proofing processes, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 3 Policy for resisting the threat of token issuance disclosure Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they resist the threat of token issuance disclosure, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 4 Technical capabilities for resisting the threat of token issuance disclosure Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to resist the threat of token issuance disclosure, as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 5 Policy for resisting the threat of token issuance tampering Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they resist the threat of token issuance tampering, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 6 Technical capabilities for resisting the threat of token issuance tampering Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to resist the threat of token issuance tampering, as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 7 Policy for resisting the threat of unauthorized token issuance Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they resist the threat of unauthorized token issuance, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 8 Technical capabilities for resisting the threat of unauthorized token issuance Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to resist the threat of unauthorized token issuance, as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 9 Policy for resisting the threat of registration repudiation Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they resist the threat of registration repudiation, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 10 Technical capabilities for resisting the threat of registration repudiation Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to resist the threat of registration repudiation, as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 11 Policy for protecting sensitive data Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they protect sensitive data, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 12 Technical capabilities for protecting sensitive data Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to protect sensitive data, as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 13 Policy for protecting the results of identity proofing Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they protect the results of identity proofing, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 14 Technical capabilities for protecting the results of identity proofing Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to protect the results of identity proofing, as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 15 Policy for maintaining records of applicants Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they maintain records of applicants, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 16 Technical capabilities for maintaining records of applicants Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to maintain records of applicants, as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 17 Policy for providing identity proofing records Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they have the capability to provide identity proofing records to RPs, as required? Document references to sections of the established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 18 Technical capabilities for providing identity proofing records Do the trustmark applicant and its LOA 2 RA designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to provide identity proofing records to RPs, as required?
